statement.tex:
%text Examine the continuity of $f(x)$ where $f(x)$ is defined as
% \qquad f(x) = \begin{cases} \sin x - \cos x,\, x\neq 0 \\ -1, \, x = 0 \end{cases}

options.tex: %text \textcolor{blue}{\text{We have to prove that }\ldots} $\ldots f(x)$ is continuous at all $x$ %

reason.tex:
%text The question clearly asks to examine the \underline\text{continuity of $f(x)$}
Which means \underline\text{all of $f(x)$} - and not just at some specific $x$. %

options.tex: %text $f(x) = \sin x-\cos x$ is continuous for all $x\neq 0$ %

reason.tex:
%text If two functions $a(x)$ and $b(x)$ are continuous in some domain, then so is $a(x) + b(x)$ and $a(x) - b(x)$.
Now, given that $\sin x$ and $\cos x$ are both continuous for $x\neq 0$, then so must $\sin x-\cos x$ be. %

options.tex: %text \[ \lim_{x\to 0} f(x) \neq f(0) \]. Hence, $f(x)$ is not continuous at $x = 0$ %

reason.tex:
\begin{align} \lim_{x\to 0} f(x) &= \lim_{x\to 0}(\sin x-\cos x) \\ &= 0 - 1 = -1 \\ \text{Also, }f(0) &= \sin 0 -\cos 0 = - 1 \end{align} %text
As \[ \lim_{x\to 0} f(x) = f(0) \], therefore $f(x)$ is \underline\text{also continuous} at $x = 0$.
Hence, $f(x)$ is continuous for $x\neq 0$ and for $x= 0 \implies f(x)$ is continuous for all $x$
%
